justification: “Choice-induced preference change was originally introduced with the free choice paradigm (Brehm, 1956).” The paradigm’s post-choice ‘spreading of alternatives’ is taken as the indicator of the construct.

“Using the choice blindness paradigm – a novel methodological tool in the study of choice-induced preference change – we test if choice-induced preference change also occurs …” indicating the paradigm is employed to measure the construct.

“The choice blindness paradigm … involves giving participants false feedback about their choices through sleight-of-hand or other forms of manipulation,” describing how the construct is operationalised.
“After participants had chosen, they completed a seven-point Likert scale indicating how high their individual confidence was in their choice.”
“Choice response times have a long history in psychology for inferences about cognitive processes and strength of preference.”

measured_by: congruence between first and second choice
justification: “We defined choice consistency as congruence between first and second choice,” specifying how the construct is quantified.
